Remark,  Theorem 3 can be generalized so as to apply without assumptions on the smoothness of the boundary of Z ).  Indeed,  it is enough to suppose that at some point P on Г there is an internally touching surface element a of class C^ whose mean curvature is negative.  ( The sign of the mean curvature is here based on the convention that the normal vector to с is directed toward the side of a which near P contains only points interior to D,  cf.  Figure 3.  This is clearly consistent with our earlier agreement concerning the sign of the mean curvature of Г.  )

Configuration for an ^^ solvable.  Thus again there obviously exists boundary data having internally touching arbitrarily small absolute value,  for which no solution of the Dirichlet surface element or atP.  problem is possible. 
When n = 2 this result can be sharpened further.  In fact,  in this case it is enough to suppose simply that D is non - convex,  for then ( by a result of Léja and Wilkosz,  cf.  [ 18 ],  Theorem 4.  8 ) there must be some boundary point P where there is an internally touching arc of a circle with negative curvature.  We thus obtain the following extension of the result of Finn which was stated in the introduction.
